metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: Matplotlib Pie Charts
Creating Pie Charts
With Pyplot, you can use the pie() function to draw pie charts:
content.html: With Pyplot, you can use the pie() function to draw pie charts:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as pltimport numpy as npy = np.array([35, 
  25, 25, 15])plt.pie(y)plt.show()

content.code:
import matplotlib.pyplot as pltimport numpy as npy = np.array([35,
25, 25, 15])plt.pie(y)plt.show()

syntax_highlighting.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as pltimport numpy as npy = np.array([35, 
 25, 25, 15])plt.pie(y)plt.show()

content.code_html:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

y = np.array([35, 25, 25, 15])

plt.pie(y)
plt.show()

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as pltimport numpy as npy = np.array([35, 
  25, 25, 15])plt.pie(y)plt.show()

content.text: As you can see the pie chart draws one piece (called a wedge) for each value in the array (in this case [35, 25, 25, 15]).
content.html: As you can see the pie chart draws one piece (called a wedge) for each value in the array (in this case [35, 25, 25, 15]).

content.text: By default the plotting of the first wedge starts from the x-axis and moves counterclockwise :
content.html: By default the plotting of the first wedge starts from the x-axis and moves counterclockwise:

content.text: Note: The size of each wedge is determined by comparing the value with all the other values, by using this formula:
content.html: Note: The size of each wedge is determined by comparing the value with all the other values, by using this formula:

content.text: The value divided by the sum of all values: x/sum(x)
content.html: The value divided by the sum of all values: x/sum(x)

content.text: Labels
Add labels to the pie chart with the labels parameter.
content.html: Add labels to the pie chart with the labels parameter.

content.text: The labels parameter must be an array with one label for each wedge:
content.html: The labels parameter must be an array with one label for each wedge:

content.code_html:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

y = np.array([35, 25, 25, 15])
mylabels = ["Apples", "Bananas", "Cherries", "Dates"]

plt.pie(y, labels = mylabels)
plt.show()

content.text: Start Angle
As mentioned the default start angle is at the x-axis, but you can change the start angle by specifying a startangle parameter.
content.html: As mentioned the default start angle is at the x-axis, but you can change the start angle by specifying a startangle parameter.

content.text: The startangle parameter is defined with an angle in degrees, default angle is 0:
content.html: The startangle parameter is defined with an angle in degrees, default angle is 0:

content.code_html:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

y = np.array([35, 25, 25, 15])
mylabels = ["Apples", "Bananas", "Cherries", "Dates"]

plt.pie(y, labels = mylabels, startangle = 90)
plt.show()

content.text: Explode
Maybe you want one of the wedges to stand out? The explode parameter allows you to do that.
content.html: Maybe you want one of the wedges to stand out? The explode parameter allows you to do that.

content.text: The explode parameter, if specified, and not None , must be an array with one value for each wedge.
content.html: The explode parameter, if specified, and not None, must be an array with one value for each wedge.

content.text: Each value represents how far from the center each wedge is displayed:
content.html: Each value represents how far from the center each wedge is displayed:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as pltimport numpy as npy = np.array([35, 
  25, 25, 15])mylabels = ["Apples", "Bananas", "Cherries", "Dates"]
  myexplode = [0.2, 0, 0, 0]plt.pie(y, 
  labels = mylabels, explode = myexplode)plt.show()

content.code:
import matplotlib.pyplot as pltimport numpy as npy = np.array([35,
25, 25, 15])mylabels = ["Apples", "Bananas", "Cherries", "Dates"]
myexplode = [0.2, 0, 0, 0]plt.pie(y,
labels = mylabels, explode = myexplode)plt.show()

syntax_highlighting.text:

  labels = mylabels, explode = myexplode)plt.show()

mylabels = ["Apples", "Bananas", "Cherries", "Dates"]
myexplode = [0.2, 0, 0, 0]

plt.pie(y, labels = mylabels, explode = myexplode)
plt.show()

content.text: Shadow
Add a shadow to the pie chart by setting the shadows parameter to True :
content.html: Add a shadow to the pie chart by setting the shadows parameter to True:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as pltimport numpy as npy = np.array([35, 
  25, 25, 15])mylabels = ["Apples", "Bananas", "Cherries", "Dates"]
  myexplode = [0.2, 0, 0, 0]plt.pie(y, 
  labels = mylabels, explode = myexplode, shadow = True)plt.show()

content.code:

myexplode = [0.2, 0, 0, 0]plt.pie(y,
labels = mylabels, explode = myexplode, shadow = True)plt.show()

content.text: Colors
You can set the color of each wedge with the colors parameter.
content.html: You can set the color of each wedge with the colors parameter.

content.text: The colors parameter, if specified, must be an array with one value for each wedge:
content.html: The colors parameter, if specified, must be an array with one value for each wedge:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as pltimport numpy as npy = np.array([35, 
  25, 25, 15])mylabels = ["Apples", "Bananas", "Cherries", "Dates"]
  mycolors = ["black", "hotpink", "b", "#4CAF50"]plt.pie(y, labels = 
  mylabels, colors = mycolors)plt.show()

content.code:
import matplotlib.pyplot as pltimport numpy as npy = np.array([35,
25, 25, 15])mylabels = ["Apples", "Bananas", "Cherries", "Dates"]
mycolors = ["black", "hotpink", "b", "#4CAF50"]plt.pie(y, labels =
mylabels, colors = mycolors)plt.show()

  mylabels, colors = mycolors)plt.show()

content.text: You can use Hexadecimal color values , any of the 140 supported color names , or one of these shortcuts:
content.html: You can use Hexadecimal color values, any of the 140 supported color names, or one of these shortcuts:

content.text: 'r' - Red 'g' - Green 'b' - Blue 'c' - Cyan 'm' - Magenta 'y' - Yellow 'k' - Black 'w' - White
content.html:
'r' - Red
'g' - Green
'b' - Blue
'c' - Cyan
'm' - Magenta
'y' - Yellow
'k' - Black
'w' - White

content.text: Legend
To add a list of explanation for each wedge, use the legend() function:
content.html: To add a list of explanation for each wedge, use the legend() function:

content.code_html:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

y = np.array([35, 25, 25, 15])
mylabels = ["Apples", "Bananas", "Cherries", "Dates"]

plt.pie(y, labels = mylabels)
plt.legend()
plt.show()

content.text: Legend With Header
To add a header to the legend, add the title parameter to the legend function.
content.html: To add a header to the legend, add the title parameter to the legend function.

content.code_html:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

y = np.array([35, 25, 25, 15])
mylabels = ["Apples", "Bananas", "Cherries", "Dates"]

plt.pie(y, labels = mylabels)
plt.legend(title = "Four Fruits:")
plt.show()
